revision.comment: the work's name is "The New York Times"; publisher=>work in cite using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2015}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Conan O'Brien | image = Conan O'Brien by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = O'Brien at the 2015 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] | birth_name = Conan Christopher O'Brien | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|4|18}} | birth_place = [[Brookline, Massachusetts|Brookline]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. | medium = Television | active = 1983–present | genre = [[Improvisational comedy]], [[sketch comedy]], [[physical comedy]], [[surreal humor]], [[self-deprecation]], [[black comedy]], [[comedy music|musical comedy]], [[satire]] | subject = [[Culture of the United States|American culture]], [[Politics of the United States|American politics]], [[everyday life]], [[pop culture]], [[World news|current events]], [[human behavior]], [[embarrassment|social awkwardness]], [[gender differences]], [[human sexuality]] | spouse = {{marriage|Elizabeth Ann Powel|2002}} | children = 2 | notable_work = {{unbulleted list|''[[The Simpsons]]''|(writer, producer, 1991–93)|''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]''|(host, 1993–2009)|''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]''|(host, 2009–2010)|''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''|(host, 2010–present)}} | signature = Conan O'Brien Signature.svg |alma_mater = [[Harvard University]]}}
'''Conan Christopher O'Brien''' (born April 18, 1963) is an American television host, comedian, writer, and producer. He is best known for hosting several [[late-night talk show]]s; since 2010, he has hosted ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' on the cable channel [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]]. O'Brien was born in [[Brookline, Massachusetts|Brookline]], [[Massachusetts]], and was raised in an [[Irish Catholic]] family. He served as president of ''[[The Harvard Lampoon]]'' while attending [[Harvard University]], and was a writer for the sketch comedy series ''[[Not Necessarily the News]]''.
After writing for several comedy shows in Los Angeles, he joined the writing staff of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. O'Brien was a writer and producer for ''[[The Simpsons]]'' for two seasons until he was commissioned by [[NBC]] to take over [[David Letterman]]'s position as host of ''[[Late Night (NBC)|Late Night]]'' in 1993. A virtual unknown to the public, O'Brien's initial ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien|Late Night]]'' tenure received unfavorable reviews and remained on a multiweek renewal cycle during its early years. The show generally improved over time and was highly regarded by the time of his departure in 2009. Afterwards, O'Brien relocated from New York to Los Angeles to host his own incarnation of ''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien|The Tonight Show]]'' for seven months until network politics prompted a [[2010 Tonight Show conflict|host change]] in 2010.
Known for his spontaneous hosting style, which has been characterized as "awkward, self-deprecating humor", O'Brien's late-night programs combine the "lewd and wacky with more elegant, narrative-driven short films (remotes)".<ref name="NewYorkT">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/24/magazine/24Conan-t.html?pagewanted=all|title= Heeeere's . . . Conan!!!|author=Lynn Hirschberg|date=May 20, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 21, 2012}}</ref> He has hosted ''Conan'' since 2010 and has also hosted such events as the [[Emmy Award]]s and ''[[Christmas in Washington]]''.<ref name="foxnewstbs">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2010/04/12/conan-obrien-debut-new-late-night-tbs/|title=Conan O'Brien to Debut New Late-Night Show on TBS|date=April 12, 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=FOX News|accessdate=April 12, 2010}}</ref><ref name="abc04122010">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=10352884|author=Frazier Moore, Associated Press|title=Conan O'Brien to Make TBS His New Late-Night Home|date=April 12, 2010|accessdate=April 12, 2010|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> O'Brien has been the subject of a documentary, ''[[Conan O'Brien Can't Stop]]'' (2011), and has also hosted a 32-city [[The Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour|live comedy tour]].
With the retirement of [[David Letterman]] on May 20, 2015, O'Brien became the longest-working<!-- TENURE a fixed period of time during which a person holds a job or position --> of all current late-night talk show hosts in the United States, at 22 years.<ref name="letterman retirement">{{cite web|url=http://www.etonline.com/tv/164753_conan_o_brien_uncomfortable_with_david_letterman_leaving_late_show/|author=Raphael Chestang|title=Conan O'Brien 'Uncomfortable' With David Letterman Leaving 'Late Show'|date=May 18, 2015|accessdate=May 25, 2015|publisher=[[Entertainment Tonight]]}}</ref>
==Early life== O'Brien was born on April 18, 1963 in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]].<ref name="tvg" /> His father, Thomas Francis O'Brien, is a physician, [[epidemiology|epidemiologist]], and professor of medicine at [[Harvard Medical School]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=May 9, 2008|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/42/Conan-O-Brien.html|title=Conan O'Brien Biography (1963–)|publisher=Film Reference}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|accessdate=May 9, 2008|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/celeb/obrien.htm|title=Conan Christopher O'Brien|publisher=Ancestry}}</ref><ref name="actors">Stated on ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]'', 2009</ref> His mother, Ruth O'Brien (née Reardon), is a retired attorney and former partner at the Boston firm [[Ropes & Gray]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=January 23, 2010|url=http://www.law.stanford.edu/library/womenslegalhistory/papers/ObrienR-Peddie97.pdf|title=Ruth Reardon O'Brien 1931–|publisher=Stanford.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Ruth-Reardon-O-Brien/6000000013451612707|title=Ruth Reardon O'Brien|website=geni_family_tree}}</ref> O'Brien has three brothers and two sisters.
O'Brien attended [[Brookline High School]], where he served as the [[managing editor]] of the [[student newspaper|school newspaper]], ''[[The Sagamore (Brookline High School)|The Sagamore]]''.<ref name=actors/> In his second year, O'Brien was an intern for [[Congressman]] [[Robert Drinan]]<ref>{{YouTube|id=qQWy40hzNKc&t=0m45s|title="Rehearsal Scraps: Andy Ruins Conan's First Real Human Moment In 15 Years – CONAN on TBS"|link=no}}</ref> and in his senior year, he won the [[National Council of Teachers of English]] writing contest with his short story, "To Bury the Living".<ref>{{cite news|title=Extra Credit: Starting Out with Style|work=The Boston Globe| date= December 3, 1980|last=Coons| first= Phyllis}}</ref> After graduating as [[valedictorian]] in 1981, he entered [[Harvard University]].<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=May 11, 2008| url= http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2003/11/06/monet_goes_to_vegas_kerry_goes_out_on_the_town/| title= Monet goes to Vegas; Kerry goes out on the town| work= Boston Globe| date= November 6, 2003|last= Beggy |first= Carol}}</ref> At Harvard, O'Brien lived in [[Holworthy Hall]] during his first year<ref>{{cite web| accessdate= May 11, 2008| url= http://www.fdo.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k3806&pageid=icb.page101294| title= Harvard College Freshman Dean's Office| publisher= [[Harvard College]]| deadurl= yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130731162551/http://www.fdo.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k3806&pageid=icb.page101294| archivedate= July 31, 2013| df= mdy-all}}</ref> and [[Mather House (Harvard University)|Mather House]] during his three upper-class years. He concentrated in history and literature and graduated ''[[magna cum laude]]''<ref name="lauf">{{cite book |last= Laufenberg| first= Norbert B.| title=Entertainment Celebrities |publisher= Trafford| year= 2005 |page= 482| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=mzTW9Nitee4C&pg=PA482&dq=Conan+O%27Brien+Laufenberg&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false | isbn=978-1-4120-5335-8}}</ref> in 1985.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u7TwqpWiY5s&NR=1 "@Google & YouTube present A Conversation with Conan O'Brien"], AtGoogleTalks, May 7, 2010.</ref> O'Brien's senior thesis concerned the use of children as symbols in the works of [[William Faulkner]] and [[Flannery O'Connor]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.boston.com/news/globe/magazine/articles/2003/08/31/understanding_conan/?page=full| last= Aucoin|first= Don|title = Understanding Conan | publisher=The Boston Globe Magazine|date = August 31, 2003}}</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uV4qMfeyQ5c&t=10m40s Conan O'Brien explaining his Harvard thesis] (interview at JFK Library, YouTube upload on Jul 11, 2012)</ref> During college, O'Brien briefly served as the drummer in a band called "The Bad Clams", was a writer for the ''[[Harvard Lampoon]]'' humor magazine,<ref>O'Brien, Conan. ''The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien'', NBC, January 15, 2010.</ref> and developed a spoof of the popular video game ''[[One on One: Dr. J vs. Larry Bird]]'' in which the [[Boston Celtics]] play against a [[classical ballet]] troupe.<ref name="maher20140620">{{cite web | url=http://www.filfre.net/2014/06/comprehend/ | title=Comprehend | work=The Digital Antiquarian | date=June 20, 2014 | accessdate=July 11, 2014 | author=Maher, Jimmy}}</ref> During his sophomore and junior years, he served as the ''Lampoon'''s president.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Star Rising|work=The Boston Globe|date=October 24, 1983|last= Longcope |first= Kay}}</ref> At this time, O'Brien's future boss at [[NBC]], [[Jeff Zucker]], was serving as President of the school's newspaper ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.deadline.com/hollywood/no-joke-jeff-zucker-had-conan-arrested/|title=NO JOKE: Jeff Zucker Had Conan Arrested|last=Finke |first= Nikki |authorlink= Nikki Finke |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]| date=January 14, 2010| accessdate=January 24, 2010}}</ref>
==Career==
===''Saturday Night Live'' (1987–1991)=== [[File:Conan O'Brien - Simpsons (cropped).jpg|right|thumb|O'Brien in the offices of the writers of ''The Simpsons'', 1992]]
O'Brien moved to Los Angeles after graduation to join the writing staff of [[Home Box Office|HBO]]'s ''[[Not Necessarily the News]]''.<ref name="avclub">{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.avclub.com/content/node/52144|title=Conan O'Brien|publisher=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=August 30, 2006|author=Rabin, Nathan}}</ref> He was also a writer on the short-lived ''[[The Wilton North Report]]''.<ref name="avclub" /> He spent two years with that show and performed regularly with [[improvisation]]al groups, including [[The Groundlings]]. In January 1988, ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'''s executive producer, [[Lorne Michaels]], hired O'Brien as a writer. During his three years on ''Saturday Night Live (SNL)'', he wrote such recurring sketches as "Mr. Short-Term memory" and "The Girl Watchers"; the latter was first performed by [[Tom Hanks]] and [[Jon Lovitz]].<ref name="speakerbio">{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.greatertalent.com/speakers/speakers.php?speakerid=235|title=Host of Late Night With Conan O'Brien|publisher=Greater Talent Network |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080418032637/http://www.greatertalent.com/speakers/speakers.php?speakerid=235 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = April 18, 2008}}</ref> O'Brien also co-wrote the sketch "Nude Beach" with [[Robert Smigel]], in which the word "penis" was said or sung at least 42 times. While on a writers' strike from ''Saturday Night Live'' following the 1987–88 season, O'Brien put on an [[improvisational comedy]] revue in Chicago with fellow ''SNL'' writers [[Bob Odenkirk]] and Robert Smigel called ''[[Happy Happy Good Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Laugh Lines The Bits and Pieces That Get Comics into the Act|work=Chicago Tribune|date=June 24, 1988|author=Boulware, Hugh}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Live, From Chicago, It's...|work=Chicago Tribune|date=July 29, 1988|author=Bommer, Lawrence}}</ref> While living in Chicago, O'Brien briefly roomed with [[Jeff Garlin]].<ref>{{cite episode|title=Jeff Garlin interview|series=[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]|airdate=2007-09-07}}</ref> In 1989, O'Brien and his fellow ''SNL'' writers received an [[Emmy Award]] for Outstanding Writing in a Comedy or Variety Series.
O'Brien, like many ''SNL'' writers, occasionally appeared as an extra in sketches; his most notable appearance was as a doorman in a sketch in which [[Tom Hanks]] was inducted into the SNL "[[Five-Timers Club]]" for hosting his fifth episode. O'Brien returned to host the show in 2001 during its 26th season. O'Brien and [[Robert Smigel]] wrote the television pilot for ''[[Lookwell]]'' starring [[Adam West]], which aired on NBC in 1991. The pilot never went to series, but it became a [[cult hit]]. It was later screened at ''The Other Network'', a festival of unaired TV pilots produced by [[Un-Cabaret]]; it featured an extended interview with O'Brien and was rerun in 2002 on the [[Trio (TV network)|Trio]] network.
Things changed for O'Brien in 1991, when in quick succession, an engagement fell through; ''Lookwell'' was not picked up; and, burned out, he quit ''Saturday Night Live''.<ref name=nymag2/> "I told Lorne Michaels I couldn't come back to work and I just needed to do something else," O'Brien recalled. "I had no plan whatsoever. I was literally in this big transition phase in my life where I decided, I'll just walk around New York City, and an idea will come to me."<ref name=ortved1>Ortved, 2009. p. 160–161</ref> [[Mike Reiss]] and [[Al Jean]], then dual [[showrunner]]s of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', called O'Brien and offered him a job. The series was notorious in the writing community at the time; O'Brien recalls "everyone wanted to be on that show, but they never hired."<ref name="ortved1" /> O'Brien was one of the first hires after the show's original crew. With the help of old Groundlings friend [[Lisa Kudrow]], O'Brien purchased an apartment in [[Beverly Hills]].<ref name=nymag2/><ref name=ortved3>Ortved, 2009. p. 163</ref> He and Kudrow became involved as well, and Kudrow believed he should begin performing rather than writing. O'Brien disagreed, feeling that Kudrow was being overly flattering and that asserting he was happy as a writer. In his speech given at Class Day at Harvard in 2000,<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://thecrimson.harvard.edu/article.aspx?ref=101192|title=O'Brien Returns to Harvard|publisher=[[Harvard Crimson]]|date=June 8, 2000|author=Volonnino, Michael R.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060915195620/http://www.thecrimson.harvard.edu/article.aspx?ref=101192|archivedate=September 15, 2006|df=mdy-all}}</ref> O'Brien credited ''The Simpsons'' with saving him, a reference to the career slump he was experiencing prior to his being hired for the show.<ref name="commencement">{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://everything2.com/index.pl?node_id=692946|title=Conan O'Brien's Commencement Speech for the Harvard Class of 2000|publisher=[[everything2]]|date=August 8, 2000}}</ref>
===''The Simpsons'' (1991–1993)=== {{quote box|align=right|width=30em|quote=I was very nervous when I started. They showed me into this office and told me to start writing down some ideas. They left me alone in that office. I left after five minutes to go get a cup of coffee. I heard a crash. I walked back to the office, and there was a hole in the window and a dead bird on the floor. Literally, in my first ten minutes at ''The Simpsons'', a bird had flown through the glass of my window, hit the far wall, broken its neck, and fallen dead on the floor. [[George Meyer]] came in and looked at it, and said, "Man, this is some kind of weird omen."|source=— O'Brien on his first moments at ''The Simpsons''<ref name="ortved1" />}}
From 1991 to 1993, O'Brien was a writer and producer for ''The Simpsons''. When O'Brien first arrived at the Fox lot, they temporarily gave him writer [[Jeff Martin (writer)|Jeff Martin]]'s office. O'Brien was nervous and self-conscious, feeling that he would embarrass himself in front of what he regarded as an intimidating collection of writers.<ref name="ortved1" /> O'Brien would pitch characters in their voices as he thought that was the norm until Reiss informed him that no one did such.<ref name=ortved2>Ortved, 2009. p. 162</ref><ref name="O'Brien">O'Brien, Conan. (2003). Commentary for "[[Marge vs. the Monorail]]", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox.</ref> He fit in quickly, commanding control of the room frequently; [[Josh Weinstein]] called it a "ten-hour Conan show, nonstop".<ref name="ortved1" /> According to John Ortved, one of his fellow writers ventured that if Conan hadn't left to do ''Late Night'', he was a shoo-in to take over as showrunner on ''The Simpsons''.<ref name="ortved1" />
When not contributing to others' scripts, O'Brien managed to craft what are regarded as some of the series' most memorable and finest episodes: "[[Marge vs. the Monorail]]" and "[[Homer Goes to College]]".<ref name="ortved1" /><ref name="EWsimp">[http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,417748~3~0~25bestand1,00.html The Family Dynamic] ''EW.com''. Retrieved on February 13, 2007</ref> Generally, critics, fans and even those who worked on the show agree that its sensibilities changed following "Marge vs. the Monorail."<ref name="ortved4" /> The show was initially a highly realistic family sitcom; after O'Brien's debut, the show took a rapid shift in the direction of the surreal.<ref name=ortved4>Ortved, 2009. p. 164</ref> Along with those episodes, he has sole writing credits on "[[New Kid on the Block]]" and "[[Treehouse of Horror IV]]", on which he wrote the episode [[Treehouse of Horror IV#Production|wraparounds]]. [[Wallace Wolodarsky]] described a "room character" Conan put on for the writers: "Conan used to do this thing called the Nervous Writer that involved him opening a can of [[Diet Coke]] and then nervously pitching a joke. He would spray Diet Coke all over himself, and that was always a source of endless amusement among us."<ref name="ortved2" /> Occasionally, fellow writers from the show would stop by O'Brien's Beverly Hills apartment.<ref name="ortved3" />
Meanwhile, ''Late Night'' host [[David Letterman]] was preparing to leave, prompting executive producer Lorne Michaels to search for a new host. Michaels approached O'Brien to produce; then-agent [[Gavin Polone]] stressed that O'Brien wanted to perform, rather than produce.<ref name="ortved4" /> He arranged with Michaels that O'Brien would do a test audition on the stage of ''[[The Tonight Show]]''. [[Jason Alexander]] and [[Mimi Rogers]] were the guests, and the audience was composed of ''Simpsons'' writers.<ref name=ortved5>Ortved, 2009. p. 165</ref> Wolodarksky recalled the experience: "Seeing this friend of yours, this guy that you worked with, walk out from behind that curtain and deliver a monologue was like something you could only dream up that you couldn’t ever imagine actually happening."<ref name="ortved5" /> The performance was beamed by satellite to New York, where Lorne Michaels and NBC executives watched. O'Brien was picked as the new host of ''Late Night'' on April 26, 1993.<ref name="NewYorkT" /> As the writers headed to the voice record for "Homer Goes to College", O'Brien received a phone call from Polone informing him of the decision. "He was passed out facedown into this horrible shag carpet. He was just quiet and comatose down there on that carpet," recalled postproduction supervisor Michael Mendel. "I remember looking at him and saying, 'Wow. Your life is about to change, in a really dramatic way.'"<ref name=ortved6>Ortved, 2009. p. 166-167</ref>
Fox, however, would not let O'Brien out of his contract. Eventually, NBC and O'Brien would split the cost to get him out of the contract.<ref name="ortved6" /><ref name="CO'Brien">O'Brien, Conan. (2004). Commentary for "[[Homer Goes to College]]", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox.</ref><ref name="Jean">Jean, Al. (2004). Commentary for "[[Cape Feare]]", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox.</ref> After O'Brien's departure, the writers at ''The Simpsons'' would watch videotaped episodes of ''Late Night'' at lunch the day following their midnight broadcast and analyze them.<ref name="ortved6" /> During his time at ''The Simpsons'', O'Brien also had a side project working with Smigel on the script for a musical film based on the "[[Hans and Franz]]" sketch from ''Saturday Night Live'', but the film was never produced.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=December 3, 2010|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,302839,00.html|title=Muscle-Man Bound|work=People |date=July 8, 1994|first=Cindy|last=Pearlman}}</ref><ref>Interview with Kevin Nealon. ''Conan''. December 2, 2010.</ref>
===''Late Night'' (1993–2009)=== {{Main|Late Night with Conan O'Brien}} ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien'', originating from Studio 6A at [[30 Rockefeller Plaza]] in New York City, premiered September 13, 1993 to unfavorable reviews from contemporary critics. This reception was not completely unsurprising; O'Brien wrote a self-deprecating ''[[The New York Times]]'' piece titled "O'Brien Flops!" on the day of the show's premiere.<ref name="nyt1">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/ref/opinion/17opclassic_conan.html|title= O'Brien Flops!|author=Conan O'Brien|date=September 13, 1993|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 21, 2012}}</ref> Critics attacked O'Brien: [[Tom Shales]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' suggested that "the host resume his previous identity, Conan O'Blivion."<ref name="NewYorkT" /><ref name="shales1">{{cite news|title=Go Gently into That Good Night, Already!|author=[[Tom Shales]]|date=October 19, 1993|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|url=http://nbckicks.tripod.com/gently.html|accessdate=August 27, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130411201729/http://nbckicks.tripod.com/gently.html|archivedate=April 11, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Generally, critics viewed O'Brien as nervous and fidgety on-camera, and that he was "too smart, too East Coast, too sophisticated, too young and even too tall to be successful."<ref name="NewYorkT" /> The show was constantly at risk for cancellation; at one low point in 1994, NBC threatened to put him on a week-to-week contract. Executives were anxious to replace him with [[Greg Kinnear]], who followed O'Brien with ''[[Later (talk show)|Later]]'' at 1:30 am.<ref name="NewYorkT" /> Interns filled empty seats in the audience while affiliates began to inquire about replacement hosts.<ref name="nymag1">{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/features/14575/index3.html|title=Conan on the Couch|author=David Bianculli|date=September 26, 2005|publisher=''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''|accessdate=December 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name="shales2">{{cite news|title=So I Was Wrong… Late Night's Late Riser|author=[[Tom Shales]]|date=June 18, 1996|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=August 27, 2013|url=http://nbckicks.tripod.com/riser.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010094505/http://nbckicks.tripod.com/riser.html|archivedate=October 10, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In one installment after a short stretch of reruns, sidekick [[Andy Richter]] described his vacation activities as follows: "I sat back and reminded myself what it's like to be unemployed." The in-joke referenced the rumors floating in the trades that NBC was near canceling the program.<ref name="tribune1">{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-06-15/features/9406150047_1_conan-o-brien-jeff-ross-robert-smigel|title= NBC's Conan O'Brien Awaits His Fate|author=David Bianculli|date=June 15, 1994|publisher=''[[Chicago Tribune]]''|accessdate=December 21, 2012}}</ref>
Things would improve slowly. Banter between O'Brien and Richter improved, and sketches grew in popularity ("If They Mated", "Desk Drive", "In the Year 2000").<ref name="shales2" /> A reliable staple involved a TV screen, lowered behind O'Brien's desk and displaying a still photo of news figure. The lips and voice of these characters – frequently a party-crazed hillbilly interpretation of [[Bill Clinton]] – were supplied by writing partner [[Robert Smigel]].<ref name="shales2" /> A turning point was David Letterman's February 1994 appearance. "It was a morale boost," said O'Brien. "I'm thinking, If the guy who created the 12:30 thing comes on and says we're smart and funny, let's go."<ref name="ew">{{cite news|title=Better Late Than Never|author=Dan Snierson|date=February 9, 1996|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=http://nbckicks.tripod.com/better.html|accessdate=August 27, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070917083401/http://nbckicks.tripod.com/better.html|archivedate=September 17, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The show went through a temporary wobble in January 1995 when Robert Smigel, feeling burned out, quit as head writer.<ref name="nymag2">{{cite news|title=The Late Conan O'Brien|author=James Kaplan|date=September 21, 1998|publisher=''New York''|accessdate=August 27, 2013|url=http://nbckicks.tripod.com/tlcob.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090413135415/http://nbckicks.tripod.com/tlcob.html|archivedate=April 13, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The show's quality improved slowly over time, and most credit O'Brien's growing comedic performance.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} Within a year, a comedic formula began to arise: the show would combine the lewd and wacky with a more elegant, narrative-driven remotes.<ref name="NewYorkT" /> Regular characters would typically include a "Masturbating Bear" and a famous remote found Conan visit a historic, Civil War-era baseball league.<ref name="NewYorkT" /> That piece was one of O'Brien's personal favorites, later remarking, "When I leave this earth, at the funeral, just show this, because this pretty much says who I'm all about."<ref name="finalshow">{{Cite episode | title = Episode dated 21 February 2009 | url =https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1375140/| series = ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien''|network =NBC| airdate = February 21, 2009 }}</ref>
O'Brien's audience, largely young and male (a coveted demographic), grew steadily and the show began to best competitors in the ratings, which it would continue to do for 15 seasons.<ref name="NewYorkT" /> In the early days of the Internet, fans launched unofficial websites, compiling precise summaries of each episode.<ref name="tvguide">{{cite news|title=Who'd Have Thought? Conan Turns Cool|author=Mark Lasswell|date=June 22, 1996|publisher=''[[TV Guide]]''|url=http://nbckicks.tripod.com/cool.html|accessdate=August 27, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505005125/http://nbckicks.tripod.com/cool.html|archivedate=May 5, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Even Tom Shales was a convert: he called the show "one of the most amazing transformations in television history."<ref name="shales2" /> Beginning in 1996, O'Brien and the ''Late Night'' writing team were nominated annually for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Variety, Music or Comedy Program#Outstanding Writing for a Variety, Music or Comedy Program|Emmy Award for Best Writing in a Comedy or Variety Series]], winning the award for the first and only time in 2007. In 1997, 2000, 2002, 2003, and 2004, he and the ''Late Night'' writing staff won the [[Writers Guild of America|Writers Guild Award]] for Best Writing in a Comedy/Variety Series. In 2001, he formed his own television production company, [[Conaco]], which subsequently shared in the production credits for ''Late Night''.<ref name=actors/>
{{As of|2005|10}}, ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien'' had for eleven years consistently attracted an audience averaging about 2.5 million viewers.<ref name="nymag1" /> The apotheosis of the ''Late Night'' remotes centered on the realization in 2006 that O'Brien bore a striking resemblance to the then female president of [[Finland]], [[Tarja Halonen]]. "We took the show to Helsinki for five days," O'Brien recalled, "where we were embraced like a national treasure."<ref name="NewYorkT" /><ref>{{cite news|accessdate=January 26, 2010|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/TRAVEL/01/26/conan.obrien.vacation/index.html?hpt=C2|title=5 places Conan should go on vacation|publisher=CNN|date=January 26, 2010|author=Barish, Mike}}</ref>
On February 20, 2009, NBC aired the last episode of ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien''. The show consisted of a compilation of previous ''Late Night'' clips and included a surprise appearance by former sidekick [[Andy Richter]]. [[Will Ferrell]], [[John Mayer]], and the [[White Stripes]] also appeared. O'Brien ended the episode by destroying the set with an axe, handing out the pieces of the set to the audience,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kirotv.com/entertainment/18729975/detail.html|title=Conan O'Brien Takes Ax To 'Late Night' Set|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=kirotv.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929000750/http://www.kirotv.com/entertainment/18729975/detail.html|archive-date=2011-09-29|dead-url=yes|accessdate=February 25, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2009/02/19/2009-02-19_conan_obrien_ends_16year_run_in_new_york.html|title=Conan O'Brien ends 16-year run in New York to take over 'Tonight Show'|last=Huff|first=Richard|date=February 19, 2009|work=|publisher=New York Daily News|accessdate=February 25, 2010}}</ref> and thanking a list of people who helped him get to that point in his career. Among those thanked were Lorne Michaels, David Letterman, [[Jay Leno]], and O'Brien's wife and children.
====The Colbert / O'Brien / Stewart mock feud==== {{Main|Who Made Huckabee?}} During the [[2007–08 Writers Guild of America strike|writers' strike]] in 2008, O'Brien staged a mock [[feud]] with [[Comedy Central]]'s [[Jon Stewart]] (of ''[[The Daily Show]]'') and [[Stephen Colbert]] (of ''[[The Colbert Report]]'') over a dispute about which of the three were responsible for giving a "bump" to [[Mike Huckabee]]'s campaign to become the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential nominee.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.today.com/id/23017599/ns/today-today_entertainment/t/conan-stewart-colbert-unite-mock-feud/#.WmoHN98oSHs|title=Conan, Stewart, Colbert unite in mock feud|date=2008-02-05|work=TODAY.com|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref> This feud crossed over all three shows during the [[2007–08 Writers Guild of America strike]].<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://embeds.blogs.foxnews.com/2008/02/06/who-created-huckabee-conan-stewart-and-colbert-fight-it-out/|title=Who Created Huckabee? Conan, Stewart, and Colbert Fight it Out|publisher=Fox News|date=February 6, 2008|author=Gomez, Fin |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080420164850/http://embeds.blogs.foxnews.com/2008/02/06/who-created-huckabee-conan-stewart-and-colbert-fight-it-out/ <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = April 20, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/06/arts/television/06late.html|title=The Story Behind a Late-Night Brawl|last=Steinberg|first=Jacques|date=2008-02-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
===''The Tonight Show'' (2009–2010)=== {{Main|The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien}} In 2004, O'Brien negotiated a new contract with [[NBC]]. As part of the deal, O'Brien would take over ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' from [[Jay Leno]] in 2009.<ref name=actors/> O'Brien was a guest on Jay Leno's final episode of ''The Tonight Show''. On June 1, 2009, [[Will Ferrell]] became Conan's first ''Tonight Show'' guest on the couch and [[Pearl Jam]] appeared as his first musical guest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.okmagazine.com/news/view/14317 |title=Will Ferrell Helps Conan Kick Things Off |work=Ok! |date=May 18, 2009 |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref>
During the taping of the Friday, September 25, 2009, episode of ''The Tonight Show'', O'Brien suffered from a mild concussion after he slipped and hit his head while running a race as part of a comedy sketch with guest [[Teri Hatcher]]. He was examined at a hospital and released the same day. A rerun was aired that night, but O'Brien returned to work the following Monday and poked fun at the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2009946418_apustvconanobrien.html|title=Conan O'Brien OK after hitting head in show stunt|accessdate=June 27, 2011 | work=The Seattle Times|first=Lynn|last=Elber|date=September 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2009-09-28-conan-returns_N.htm|title=O'Brien back on 'Tonight,' joking about accident|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=August 27, 2013|date=September 28, 2009}}</ref>
====Departure from ''The Tonight Show''==== {{Main|2010 Tonight Show conflict}} [[File:Conan O'Brien speaking at TBS rally crop.jpg|thumb|left|upright|O'Brien in [[Atlanta]], Georgia, June 2010]] On Thursday, January 7, 2010, NBC executive Jeff Zucker met with Jay Leno and Conan O'Brien to discuss how to get Leno out of prime time, where his ratings were lackluster, and back into late night, where O'Brien's ratings had collapsed before Leno's prime time series began. A proposal was made that would see O'Brien remain as host of ''The Tonight Show'', which would be moved to 12:05 am with Leno hosting a 30-minute [[The Jay Leno Show|show]] at 11:35 pm<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/08/business/media/08leno.html?ref=business|title=NBC Wants Leno Back in Old Slot|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 8, 2010 | first=Bill | last=Carter | date=January 8, 2010}}</ref> On January 10, [[NBC Universal]] Television Entertainment chairman Jeff Gaspin confirmed that ''The Jay Leno Show'' would indeed end at the start of the Winter Olympics on February 12, 2010, and be moved to 11:35 pm following the Olympics coverage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/tv/story/2010/01/10/nbc-leno-return.html |title=Leno returns to late night: NBC |date=January 10, 2010 |accessdate=January 10, 2010 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100112015459/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/tv/story/2010/01/10/nbc-leno-return.html |archivedate=January 12, 2010 }}</ref> Sources familiar with the situation told the ''[[New York Post]]'' that O'Brien was unhappy with NBC's plan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/just_call_him_conan_flyin_ThND8Mdv5MI5Pv8udof1LJ|title=Just Call Him Conan O'Flyin'|date=January 11, 2010|accessdate=January 11, 2010|work=New York Post | first1=Sean | last1=Daly}}</ref>
{{Quote box|Every comedian, every comedian dreams of hosting ''The Tonight Show'' and—for seven months—I got to do it. I did it my way, with people I love, and I do not regret a second [of it].... All I ask is one thing, and I'm asking this particularly of young people that watch: Please do not be cynical. I hate cynicism; for the record it's my least favorite quality. It doesn't lead anywhere. Nobody in life gets exactly what they thought they were going to get. But if you work really hard and you're kind, amazing things will happen.|align=right |width=30%|source=—Conan O'Brien, on his departure from ''The Tonight Show'', January 22, 2010<ref>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/achenblog/2010/01/conan_obrien_farewell.html|title= Classily, Conan exits the Tonight Show|accessdate=January 22, 2010|publisher=DETNEWS|year=2010 |author=Graham, Adam}}</ref>}} On January 12, O'Brien released this statement: "I sincerely believe that delaying ''The Tonight Show'' into the next day to accommodate another comedy program will seriously damage what I consider to be the greatest franchise in the history of broadcasting. ''The Tonight Show'' at 12:05 simply isn’t ''The Tonight Show.''"<ref>[http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/12/conan-obrien-says-he-wont-do-tonight-show-following-leno Conan O'Brien Says He Won't Host "Tonight Show" After Leno], ''The New York Times'', January 12, 2010</ref><ref>[http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2010/01/conan-obrien-i-wont-do-the-tonight-show-at-1205.html Conan O'Brien: I Won't Do "The Tonight Show" at 12:05AM] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115045853/http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2010/01/conan-obrien-i-wont-do-the-tonight-show-at-1205.html |date=January 15, 2010 }}, ''Zap2It.com'', January 12, 2010</ref> On January 21, 2010, it was announced that Conan had reached a deal with NBC that would see him exit ''The Tonight Show'' the next day. The deal also granted him $45 million, of which $12 million was designated for distribution to his staff, who had moved with Conan to Los Angeles from New York when he left ''Late Night''.
The final ''Tonight Show'' with Conan aired January 22, 2010, and featured guests [[Tom Hanks]], [[Steve Carell]] (who did an exit interview and shredded Conan's [[ID badge]]), [[Neil Young]] (singing "[[Long May You Run]]"), and [[Will Ferrell]]. For Ferrell's appearance, Conan played guitar with the band and Ferrell sang "[[Free Bird]]" while reprising his ''[[Saturday Night Live|SNL]]'' [[more cowbell|cowbell]]. Ferrell's wife, [[Viveca Paulin]], together with [[Ben Harper]], [[Beck]], and [[ZZ Top]] guitarist [[Billy Gibbons]], also joined the band for this final performance.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2010/01/23/arts/entertainment-us-nbc-obrien.html?_r=1 Conan O'Brien Thanks Fans in "Tonight" Farewell], ''The New York Times'', January 23, 2010</ref>
Jay Leno returned to ''The Tonight Show'' following NBC's coverage of the 2010 Winter Olympic Games. Under the $45 million deal with NBC, Conan was allowed to start working for another network as soon as September 2010.<ref>[http://www.thewrap.com/ind-column/new-nbc-breaking-story-13241 Exclusive: Conan, NBC Officially Splitsville], ''The Wrap'', January 21, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/444477-NBC_Conan_O_Brien_Reach_Deal_for_Tonight_Show_Exit.php NBC, Conan O'Brien Reach Deal for "Tonight Show" Exit], ''Broadcasting & Cable'', January 21, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/obrien-signs-deal-to-leave-nbc-2010-01-21 Conan O'Brien Signs Deal to Leave NBC], ''MarketWatch'', January 21, 2010</ref> Conan's rumored next networks ranged anywhere from Fox<ref name="nyt 010810">''[[The New York Times]]'' article: "[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/09/arts/television/09leno.html NBC’s Shift in Schedule May Be Up to O’Brien]".</ref> to [[Comedy Central]].<ref name="bi012210">Business Insider article: "[http://www.businessinsider.com/conan-obrien-mulling-cable-as-fx-usa-comedy-central-hbo-showtime-put-out-feelers-2010-1 Why Is USA Network, NBC's Sister Station, Wooing Conan?]".</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Brian |last=Gallagher |url=http://www.movieweb.com/news/NErxpxvwq6pAux |title=Conan O'Brien Mulls Post The Tonight Show Options |publisher=MovieWeb.com |date=January 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref>
===After ''The Tonight Show''=== On February 8, 2010, it was reported that O'Brien was attempting to sell his [[Central Park West]] penthouse in New York with an asking price of $35 million.<ref name="tbi">''Business Insider'' article: "[http://www.businessinsider.com/conan-obrien-selling-his-new-york-apartment-2010-2 Conan O'Brien Staying Close To Fox, Selling His New York Apartment]."</ref> He had purchased the apartment in 2007 for $10 million.<ref name="tbi" /> Two years earlier, O'Brien had purchased a home in the [[Brentwood, Los Angeles|Brentwood]] section of Los Angeles for over $10.5 million.<ref name="latimes-home">{{cite news|title=Conan O'Brien's palatial Brentwood home|url=http://www.latimes.com/classified/realestate/la-re-conan29feb29.pg,0,1321380.photogallery|work=Los Angeles Times|date=February 27, 2008|accessdate=August 27, 2013}}</ref> Some industry insiders have speculated that O'Brien had chosen to stay on the west coast in order to facilitate a return to late night television<ref name="tbi"/> and because he did not want to put his children through another move.<ref name="stayinginla">Behrens, Zach (April 27, 2010). [http://laist.com/2010/04/27/conan_says_hell_stay_in_la_for_cabl.php "Conan Says He'll Stay in L.A. for Cable Show, Will Appear on '60 Minutes'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100502000813/http://laist.com/2010/04/27/conan_says_hell_stay_in_la_for_cabl.php |date=May 2, 2010 }}". [[LAist]].</ref>
On February 24, 2010, O'Brien attracted media attention for starting a Twitter account.<ref name="twitter">[https://twitter.com/ConanOBrien Conan O'Brien] at Twitter</ref><ref name="ewtwit">''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' article: "[http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/02/25/conan-obrien-twitter/ Conan O'Brien's Twitter debut]."</ref> His tweets, although primarily jokes, amounted to his first public statements since leaving ''The Tonight Show'' one month earlier.<ref name="chitwitter" /> After about one hour, O'Brien's subscriber list had rocketed to over 30,000 members, and approximately 30 minutes later he was on the brink of passing 50,000 followers, already 20,000 more than the verified @jayleno account.<ref name="cnettwitter">[[Cnet]] article: "[http://news.cnet.com/8301-17852_3-10459535-71.html?part=rss&subj=news&tag=2547-1_3-0-20 Conan joins Twitter, beats Leno in hours]."</ref><ref name="latwitter">''[[LA Times]]'' article: "[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/02/conan-obrien-twitter-jay-leno.html Conan O'Brien joins Twitter and doubles Jay Leno's follower count in two hours]."</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Conan O'Brien Joins Twitter: New Account EXPLODES With Followers|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=First Posted: 02–24–10 06:16 pm; Updated: 04–26–10 05:12 am|accessdate=October 13, 2010|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/02/24/conan-obrien-joins-twitte_n_475722.html|first=Craig|last=Kanalley}}</ref> After 24 hours, O'Brien had well over 300,000 followers.<ref name="chitwitter">''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' article: "[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/ct-talk-celebrities-on-twitter-0226-20100225,0,5349663.story Conan, Ozzie and the Dalai Lama: Together on Twitter]."</ref> In late May 2010, he surpassed the one million mark for number of Twitter followers,<ref name="1 million twitter">''[[USA Today]]'' article: "[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2010/05/tweet-this-conan-reaches-1-million-britney-overtakes-ashton-/1 Tweet this: Conan reaches 1 million; Britney overtakes Ashton]."</ref> and {{as of|2018|06|lc=yes}} he has over twenty nine million followers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/conanobrien |title=Conan O'Brien on Twitter |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-25}}</ref>
O'Brien has been named to the 2010 [[Time 100]], a list compiled by TIME of the 100 most influential people in the world as voted on by readers.<ref name="time100">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1984685_1984940_1985538,00.html|first=George|last=Lopez|title=Conan O'Brien – The 2010 Time 100|date=April 29, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2010|work=TIME}}</ref> After being prohibited from making television appearances of any kind until May, O'Brien spoke about the ''Tonight Show'' conflict on the [[CBS]] newsmagazine ''[[60 Minutes]]'' on May 2, 2010.<ref name="60minutes">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/30/arts/television/30conan.html|first=Bill|last=Carter|title=Conan O'Brien Opens Up About NBC Departure|date=April 29, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2010|work=The New York Times}}</ref> During the interview with [[Steve Kroft]], O'Brien said the situation felt "like a marriage breaking up suddenly, violently, quickly. And I was just trying to figure out what happened." He also said he "absolutely" expected NBC to give him more of a chance and that, if in Jay Leno's position, he would not have come back to ''The Tonight Show''. However, Conan said he did not feel he got shafted. "It's crucial to me that anyone seeing this, if they take anything away from this, it's I'm fine. I'm doing great," said O'Brien. "I hope people still find me comedically absurd and ridiculous. And I don't regret anything."<ref name="cbsinterview">{{cite news|url=http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/05/conan-60-minutes-transcript.html|title=Conan O'Brien '60 Minutes' transcript|date=May 2, 2010|accessdate=May 2, 2010|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=James|last=Hibberd|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504221851/http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/05/conan-60-minutes-transcript.html|archivedate=May 4, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
====The Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour==== [[File:Conan Legally Prohibited San Diego.jpg|thumb|right|O'Brien performing in a replica of the costume [[Eddie Murphy]] wore in ''[[Eddie Murphy Raw]]'']] {{Main|The Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour}} On March 11, 2010, O'Brien announced via his Twitter account that he would embark on a 30-city live tour beginning April 12, 2010, entitled "[[The Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour]]".<ref name="twittour">Twitter page for Conan O'Brien: "[https://twitter.com/ConanOBrien/status/10326418664 Hey Internet]."</ref><ref name="teamcoco.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.teamcoco.com/ |title=O'Brien's's Tour Site |publisher=Teamcoco.com |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref> Co-host [[Andy Richter]], along with members of the former [[The Legally Prohibited Band|Tonight Show Band]], joined O'Brien on the tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/conan-obrien-announces-live-tour-us-canada/story?id=10073505 |title=Conan O'Brien Announces Live Tour Across U.S., Canada – ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref> [[Max Weinberg]], however, was not able to join,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://weblogs.variety.com/on_the_air/2010/03/coco-coast-to-coast-conan-obrien-announces-his-national-tour.html | work=Variety | title=Coco Coast to Coast: Conan O'Brien announces his national tour (UPDATED) | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729193158/http://weblogs.variety.com/on_the_air/2010/03/coco-coast-to-coast-conan-obrien-announces-his-national-tour.html | archivedate=July 29, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> except for a guest appearance at one of Conan's New York City shows.
On April 12, 2010, O'Brien opened his two-month comedy tour in [[Eugene, Oregon]], with a crowd of 2,500 and no TV cameras. The tour traveled through America's Northwest and Canada before moving on to larger cities, including Los Angeles and New York City, where he performed on the campuses that house both of the NBC-owned studios he formerly occupied. The tour ended in [[Atlanta]] on June 14.
===''Conan'' (2010–present)=== {{Main|Conan (talk show)}} On April 12, 2010, just hours before the start of his tour in [[Eugene, Oregon]], O'Brien announced that he would host a new show on cable station [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]].<ref name="foxnewstbs" /> The show debuted on November 8, 2010,<ref>"Jack White will perform in the first show" (spanish) [http://www.cyanmag.com/revista/14/noticias-musica-14/ CYAN mag #14] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101113051906/http://www.cyanmag.com/revista/14/noticias-musica-14/ |date=November 13, 2010 }} November'10</ref> and airs Monday through Thursday beginning at 11:00 pm ET/10:00 pm CT. O'Brien's addition moved ''[[Lopez Tonight]]'' with [[George Lopez]] back one hour to midnight ET/11:00 pm CT.<ref name="abc04122010"/> Refusing at first to do to Lopez what had happened to him at NBC, O'Brien agreed to join the network after Lopez called to persuade him to come to TBS.<ref name="conantbs">{{cite news|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/12/how-the-conan-obrien-tbs-deal-happened/?src=busln|first=Bill|last=Carter|title=How the Conan O'Brien-TBS Deal Happened|date=April 12, 2010|accessdate=April 12, 2010|work=The New York Times}}</ref> In Canada, [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] would air the show<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shows.ctv.ca/allshows/article/CTV-2010-fall-schedules-and-lineups-announced#c_0 |title=Inside Shows – CTV 2010 fall schedules and lineups announced |publisher=Shows.ctv.ca |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726175530/http://shows.ctv.ca/allshows/article/CTV-2010-fall-schedules-and-lineups-announced#c_0 |archivedate=July 26, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and in Turkey, [[CNBC-e]] would air the show.
Other networks that were reportedly interested in O'Brien include TBS' sister networks [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]] and [[HBO]], [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], [[FX (TV channel)|FX]], [[Comedy Central]], [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]], [[Revision3]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://revision3.com/blog/2010/01/18/an-open-letter-to-conan-obrien/ |title=> Blog > An Open Letter to Conan O'Brien |publisher=Revision3 |date=January 18, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110226005117/http://revision3.com/blog/2010/01/18/an-open-letter-to-conan-obrien/ |archivedate=February 26, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and even the [[NBC Universal]]–owned [[USA Network]].<ref name="headlineplanet">HeadlinePlanet.com article "[http://headlineplanet.com/home/2010/01/21/report-fox-tbs-fx-hbo-among-networks-interested-in-conan-obrien/ Report: FOX, TBS, FX, HBO Among Networks Interested in Conan O’Brien]".</ref>
On September 1, 2010, O'Brien announced via his Twitter account and Team Coco YouTube page that the title of his new show on TBS would simply be ''Conan''. In 2014, TBS extended the show through 2018.<ref>{{cite news|title=TBS Signs Conan O'Brien to 4 More Years|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/15/business/media/tbs-signs-conan-obrien-to-4-more-years.html?_r=0|work=[[The New York Times]]| first=Bill|last=Carter|date=May 14, 2014}}</ref> In 2017, the show was extended through 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/conan-obrien-new-4-year-deal-tbs-1202095437/|title=Conan O’Brien Signs 4-Year TBS Deal; Says Show Will Become Leaner, More Agile, Less Predictable|first=Lisa de|last=Moraes|date=May 17, 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
In February 2015, following the onset of the [[Cuban Thaw]], O'Brien became the first American television personality to film in [[Cuba]] for more than half a century.<ref>{{cite news |first= Lisa Respers |last= France |url= http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/16/entertainment/feat-conan-obrien-show-cuba/ |publisher= CNN |title= Conan O'Brien Takes Show to Cuba |date= February 16, 2015 |access-date= February 17, 2015}}</ref> Conan O'Brien then visited [[Armenia]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Snierson|first1=Dan|title=Conan O'Brien is taking his late-night talk show to Armenia|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/10/12/conan-obrien-armenia|agency=Entertainment Weekly|date=October 12, 2015}}</ref> In April 2016, O'Brien visited [[South Korea]] in response to a fan letter urging him to visit, as well as a growing fan base online. His visit included a trip to the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone]], which resulted in O'Brien and [[Steven Yeun]] to also visit [[North Korea]] on a technicality by stepping across the border line at the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone|DMZ]]. Conan commented on the significance during the sketch, claiming, "The idea that you and I could be in North Korea, talking and communicating freely, seems like kind of a cool message."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/659047/watch-american-diplomat-conan-obrien-host-a-talk-show-on-the-north-korean-side-of-the-dmz/|title=Watch American diplomat Conan O’Brien host a talk show on the North Korean side of the DMZ|last=Epstein|first=Adam|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-09-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Television writer/producer (2002–present)=== In 2004, O'Brien apologized to Canadians for engaging in [[Quebec bashing]], something which some felt reflected prejudice against Francophones.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/18/leisure.obrien.reut/|title= Conan O'Brien apologizes to Canadians |publisher=CNN | date=February 18, 2004 | accessdate=March 31, 2010}}</ref> On March 7, 2006, NBC announced a new adventure/comedy series entitled ''[[Andy Barker, P.I.]]'', starring O'Brien's former sidekick, [[Andy Richter]]. O'Brien was executive producer and co-wrote the pilot. After six episodes and low ratings, the show was canceled despite being named by ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' as one of the Top Ten Shows of 2007.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20162677_20164091_20166802,00.html|title=Andy Barker, P.I.|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=December 21, 2007|author=Flynn, Gillian}}</ref> [[USA Network]] handed out a 90-minute, cast-contingent pilot order to the medical-themed ''Operating Instructions'' from O'Brien's production banner. O'Brien served as an executive producer through his [[Conaco]] label. The script came from ''[[Just Shoot Me]]'' veterans Judd Pillot and John Peaslee who also executive produced."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080918/tv_nm/usa_dc|title=Conan O'Brien scrubs up for medical drama – Yahoo! News|publisher=News.yahoo.com|accessdate=October 13, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080930222951/http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080918/tv_nm/usa_dc|archivedate=September 30, 2008}}</ref> [[NBC]] ordered two pilots from Conaco in January 2010, the one-hour courtroom drama, ''[[Outlaw (TV series)|Outlaw]]'', and a half-hour comedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/ustv/news/a199645/nbc-orders-pilot-from-conan-obrien.html |title=Television – News – NBC orders pilot from Conan O'Brien |publisher=Digital Spy |date=January 27, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref> ''Outlaw'' was produced in eight episodes and premiered on September 15, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2010/05/16/nbc-unveils-2010-2011-primetime-schedule/20100516nbc01/|title=NBC Unveils 2010–2011 Primetime Schedule Accented by Five New Comedies, Seven New Dramas, and New Alternative Program|date=May 16, 2010|work=The Futon Critic|accessdate=May 28, 2010}}</ref>
===Voice work and guest appearances=== O'Brien's first guest appearance after beginning his late-night career was on the show he used to write for, ''The Simpsons''. He played himself in the [[The Simpsons (season 5)|season five]] episode "[[Bart Gets Famous]]", interviewing [[Bart Simpson]] during his rise to fame as a [[catchphrase]] comedian. The episode was produced after O'Brien's audition to replace [[David Letterman]], but before he was hired for the show. O'Brien recorded his part after his own show went on the air, though he believed his show would be canceled by the time "Bart Gets Famous" aired.<ref>O'Brien, Conan. (2004). Commentary for "Bart Gets Famous" in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox.</ref> In 2006, he voiced himself in a short ''South Park'' scene as part of the opening of the 2006 [[Emmy Awards]]. In 2005, he provided the voice of [[Robert Todd Lincoln]] in the [[audiobook]] version of ''[[Assassination Vacation]]'' by [[Sarah Vowell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lodingo.com/_product_54365/Assassination_Vacation |title=LoDingo® – Assassination Vacation by Sarah Vowell – Audio Book Download |publisher=Lodingo.com |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref>
O'Brien has made multiple voice appearances on the [[Adult Swim]] series ''[[Robot Chicken]]'', including the specials ''[[Robot Chicken Star Wars|Robot Chicken: Star Wars]]'', and ''[[Robot Chicken: Star Wars Episode II]]'' as the voice of the bounty hunter Zuckuss.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tower.com/robot-chicken-star-wars-hulk-hogan-dvd/wapi/111835834 |title=DVD: Robot Chicken: Star Wars with Hulk Hogan (voice) and Conan O'Brien (voice) |publisher=Tower.com |date=July 22, 2008 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604012546/http://www.tower.com/robot-chicken-star-wars-hulk-hogan-dvd/wapi/111835834 |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> On the TV show ''[[30 Rock]]'', O'Brien is depicted as an ex-boyfriend of lead character [[Liz Lemon]], who works in the same building. In the episode "[[Tracy Does Conan]]", Conan appears as himself, awkwardly reunited with Lemon and coerced by network executive [[Jack Donaghy]] into having the character [[Tracy Jordan]] on ''Late Night'', despite having been assaulted in Jordan's previous appearance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0876931/|title="30 Rock" Tracy Does Conan (TV Episode 2006)|author=EvanHamilton|date=July 11, 2011|work=IMDb|accessdate=March 17, 2015}}</ref>
O'Brien made an appearance on ''[[Futurama]]'' in the second-season episode "[[Xmas Story]]". O'Brien plays himself as a [[Isolated brain|head in a jar]] and still alive in the year 3000. O'Brien performs a stand-up routine at a futuristic ski lodge while being heckled by [[Bender (Futurama)|Bender]] the robot.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0584465/|title="Futurama" Xmas Story (TV Episode 1999)|author=WakenPayne|date=December 22, 2013|work=IMDb|accessdate=March 17, 2015}}</ref>
O'Brien also made a cameo appearance on the U.S. version of ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]''. In the episode "[[Valentine's Day (The Office)|Valentine's Day]]", [[Michael Scott (The Office)|Michael]] believes that he spots former ''[[Saturday Night Live|SNL]]'' cast member, [[Tina Fey]], but has actually mistaken another woman for her. In the meantime, Conan has a quick walk-on and the camera crew informs Michael, when he returns from talking to the Tina Fey lookalike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/the-office/valentines-day/episode/621947/summary.html |title=The Office: Valentine's Day Episode Summary on |publisher=Tv.com |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref>
In January 2010, O'Brien appeared in ''[[The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special – In 3-D! On Ice!]]'' to honor the show he had written for in the early 1990s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/11/the-simpsons-anniversary_n_418370.html |title="The Simpsons" Anniversary: Memories From Sting, Conan O'Brien, And More (VIDEO) |work=Huffington Post |date=January 13, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |first=Dan |last=Abramson}}</ref>
O'Brien created a superhero character with veteran [[DC Comics]] animator [[Bruce Timm]] during one episode of ''Conan''. Named "The Flaming C", the superhero bears a likeness to O'Brien, with a typically muscular superhero body and costume with chest insignia, but also with idiosyncrasies arbitrarily suggested by O'Brien like an oven mitt, a [[jai alai]] glove, marijuana leaf buckle, golf shoes, sock garters and fishnet stockings.<ref>"Conan Gets Animated", [[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'', [[Turner Broadcasting System|TBS]], December 9, 2010</ref> O'Brien later aired a clip in which the character appears in ''[[Young Justice (TV series)|Young Justice]]''.<ref name="flamingc">{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs.com/video/conan.jsp?oid=239470&eref=sharethisUrl |title="The Flaming C" Returns! |publisher=Team Coco/[[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] |work=''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' |accessdate=January 11, 2011 |date=January 10, 2011}}</ref>
Since 2011, O'Brien has hosted the ''[[Christmas in Washington]]'' special for TBS' sister network, [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]], featuring celebrity performances and a special appearance by the [[Obama family]].<ref name="xmas in dc">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/2011/12/11/gIQAORUooO_story.html |title=Justin Bieber, Jennifer Hudson, others take the stage at 'Christmas in Washington'|publisher=Washington Post |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |date=December 11, 2011 |first=Phil |last=Zabriskie}}</ref>
In late 2011, he starred as himself in the web series ''[[Web Therapy]]'' (opposite [[Lisa Kudrow]]) for three episodes.
O'Brien provides the voice of the character Kuchikukan in the upcoming "[[List of The Penguins of Madagascar episodes#Unaired episodes|Operation: Lunacorn Apocalypse]]" episode of Nickelodeon's ''[[The Penguins of Madagascar]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nick.com/videos/clip/penguins-of-madagascar-309-cart-c.html |title=Penguins of Madagascar: "Lunacorn Apocalypse" S3 |publisher=[[Nickelodeon]] |accessdate=June 27, 2012}}</ref>
O'Brien provided the voice of talk show host Dave Endochrine in the 2013 [[DC Universe Animated Original Movies|DC Universe animated original movie]] ''[[Batman: The Dark Knight Returns (film)|Batman: The Dark Knight Returns (Part 2)]]''.
Twice Conan has served as the master of ceremonies for the [[White House Correspondents' Association]] dinner in Washington, D.C., in 1995 and again in 2013.
O'Brien hosted the [[2014 MTV Movie Awards]] on April 13, 2014 at the [[Microsoft Theater|Nokia Theatre L.A. Live]].<ref>[http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1723509/conan-obrien-mtv-movie-awards.jhtml "It's Official: Conan O'Brien To Host The 2014 MTV Movie Awards"] MTV.com, March 4, 2014</ref>
===Emmy host=== O'Brien hosted the [[58th Primetime Emmy Awards]] on August 27, 2006, to critical acclaim.<ref name="variety">{{cite news|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117931393?categoryid=1264&cs=1|title = article|work=Variety |date=August 27, 2006|last=Adalian|first = Josef}}</ref> He had previously hosted the [[54th Primetime Emmy Awards]] in 2002, the show was met with similar reviews.
===Commercials and product placements=== According to Marketing Evolutions, the company that produces [[Q Score]]s measuring the familiarity and appeal of celebrities and brands, almost 74% of U.S. consumers are familiar with O'Brien.<ref name="wsj2010"/> In spite of that high score, O'Brien hasn't done many commercials for corporate America; two recent examples are a 2009 appearance in a [[Super Bowl XLIII]] commercial for [[Bud Light]], and one for [[American Express]], which debuted on the same day as ''Conan''.<ref name="wsj2010">{{cite news| accessdate=November 9, 2010|url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704405704575596860479420010|title= Card for a Card: AmEx Hires Conan|work=Wall Street Journal|date=November 8, 2010|last=Vranica | first=Suzanne}}</ref> He donated his proceeds from the Super Bowl commercial to the Fresh Air Fund, a charity which sends inner-city New York children to the country for vacations.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.i4u.com/article23001.html | title= Conan O'Brien Bud Light Super Bowl 2009 Ad| date= February 1, 2009| publisher=I4U | accessdate=November 20, 2010}}</ref> According to ''The Wall Street Journal'', O'Brien was paid more than one million dollars to do the [[American Express]] commercial, which required him to spend three days in [[Jaipur]], India filming it.<ref name="wsj2010"/>
While O'Brien has done few commercials, he "does do plenty of promoting, weaving product pitches into his show"; he has said "it's increasingly incumbent to help with tie-ins [but] if it can't be funny, I'd rather go hungry."<ref name="wsj2010"/>
===Nicknames=== [[File:Im With Coco.jpg|upright|thumb|A poster created by [[Mike Mitchell (artist)|Mike Mitchell]] during the [[2010 Tonight Show conflict]] displaying his "Coco" nickname]] Conan acquired the nickname "'''Coco'''" after its use in the first "Twitter Tracker" sketch during the second episode of his ''Tonight Show'' run.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/twitter-tracker-060209/1116881/ |title=Twitter Tracker, 2 June 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2010 |publisher=tonightshowwithconanobrien.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090706084046/http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/twitter-tracker-060209/1116881/ |archivedate=July 6, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Guest [[Tom Hanks]] used the nickname during his subsequent interview, even getting the audience to chant it. In reaction to the [[moniker]], Conan remarked to Hanks in jest, "If that catches on, I'll sue you."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/tom-hanks-interview-pt-1-060209/1116835/ |title=Tom Hanks Interview Pt. 1, 2 June 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2010 |publisher=tonightshowwithconanobrien.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813001001/http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/tom-hanks-interview-pt-1-060209/1116835/ |archivedate=August 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/tom-hanks-interview-pt-2-060209/1116734/ |title=Tom Hanks Interview Pt. 2, 2 June 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2010 |publisher=tonightshowwithconanobrien.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813024814/http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/tom-hanks-interview-pt-2-060209/1116734/ |archivedate=August 13, 2009 }}</ref>
In a March 23, 2011 interview with [[WWE]] [[WWE World Heavyweight Championship|Champion]] [[The Miz]] on ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'', The Miz dubbed Conan '''"The Ginja Ninja"''', a reference to Conan's [[red hair]] and the fact that he came back fighting to get his new late-night talk show. A week later, "Team Ginja Ninja" T-shirts were available on TeamCoco.com.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://teamcoco.com/content/look-out-ginja-ninja-t-shirts-are-here|title = Look Out! The Ginja Ninja T-Shirts Are Here!|accessdate =April 8, 2011|publisher=teamcoco.com}}</ref>
==Influences== O'Brien lists among his comedic influences [[David Letterman]], [[Peter Sellers]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Houpt|first=Simon|title=Conan gets creative with his Canadian invasion|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=February 7, 2004|location=Toronto|page=R1}}</ref> [[Sid Caesar]],<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/19/conan-mel-brooks-sid-caesar_n_4816130.html | title = Conan O'Brien & Mel Brooks Remember The Brilliance of Sid Caesar}}</ref> [[Warner Bros. Cartoons]],<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2007/08/conan200708 | title = A Q&A with Conan O'Brien | work=Vanity Fair}}</ref> [[Johnny Carson]],<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.pbs.org/wnet/americanmasters/episodes/johnny-carson-king-of-late-night/about-the-documentary/2051/ | title = Johnny Carson: King of Late Night – About the Documentary}}</ref> [[Ernie Kovacs]],<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://splitsider.com/2012/01/conan-obrien-and-the-legacy-of-ernie-kovacs/ | title = Conan O'Brien and the Legacy of Ernie Kovacs}}</ref> [[Robin Williams]], [[Bob Hope]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-05-26/lifestyle/9805220392_1_bob-hope-uso-show-boat-show|title=Bob Hope Made Comedy What It Is Today|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel]] via [[The New York Times]]|date=May 26, 1998|author=O'Brien, Conan}}</ref> and [[Woody Allen]].<ref>Inside Comedy, Season 4 Episode 6</ref> In turn, actors and comedians who claim O'Brien as an influence include [[Mindy Kaling]],<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e7f-R5ipL30 | title = Mindy Kaling Was A Conan Intern – CONAN on TBS – YouTube}}</ref> [[Pete Holmes]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dBjCLD1AWMs|title=#MeetPete Facebook Questions|date=October 3, 2013|work=YouTube|accessdate=March 17, 2015}}</ref> and [[James Corden]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teamcoco.com/celebs/james-corden|title=James Corden: Conan|publisher=team coco|date=March 26, 2015|accessdate=March 26, 2015}}</ref>
On ''Late Night,'' O'Brien became known for his active and [[Ad libitum|spontaneous]] hosting style,<ref name=actors/> which has been characterized as "awkward, self-deprecating humor".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2009/06/02/awkward_self_deprecating_humor_makes_a_r_1 |title=Awkward, Self-Deprecating Humor Makes A Return As Conan O'Brien Debuts in LA |publisher=Starpulse.com |date=June 2, 2009 |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:O'Brien, Conan (with Elizabeth Ann Powel).jpg|thumb|upright|O'Brien with his wife Liza in 2007]] O'Brien met Elizabeth Ann 'Liza' Powel in 2000, when she appeared on ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien'' in an advertising skit<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/8841769|title=Conan meets Liza Powel at Foote, Cone & Belding|publisher=Vimeo|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref> involving [[Draftfcb|Foote, Cone & Belding]], where she worked as senior copywriter.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=https://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b51057_Conans_Baby_OBrien.html | archive-date =2009-02-17 | deadurl = yes | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217032247/http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b51057_Conans_Baby_OBrien.html |title=Conan's Baby O'Brien|publisher=[[E! Online]]|date=November 10, 2005|author=Serpe, Gina}}</ref> The couple dated for nearly 18 months before their 2002 marriage in Powel's hometown of [[Seattle]]. O'Brien and Powel have a daughter, Neve (born October 14, 2003)<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/2003-10-15-obrian-baby_x.htm|title=Conan O'Brien and wife have baby girl|work=USA Today|date=October 15, 2003}}</ref> and a son, Beckett (born November 9, 2005).<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1128416,00.html|archive-date=January 26, 2008|deadurl=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080126195932/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C1128416%2C00.html|title=Conan O'Brien & Wife Have Second Child|publisher=[[People magazine]]|date=November 11, 2005|df=mdy-all}}</ref> O'Brien often affirms his [[Irish Catholic]] heritage on his show. On a 2009 episode of ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]'', he stated that ancestors from both sides of his family moved to America from Ireland starting in the 1850s, subsequently marrying only other Irish Catholics, and that his lineage is thus 100% Irish Catholic.<ref name=actors/>
He has been a staunch [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] since casting his first vote for President in 1984 for [[Walter Mondale]]. He considers himself a [[centrism|moderate]] on the political spectrum.<ref name=actors/> O'Brien's longtime friend and former dormmate in Mather House at Harvard is Father Paul B. O' Brien, with whom he founded ''Labels Are For Jars'',<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.labelsareforjars.org|title=Labels are for Jars|publisher=Labels are for Jars}}</ref> an antihunger organization based in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]], and helped open the ''Cor Unum'' meal center in 2006.<ref>Betances, Yadira, [https://archive.is/20120728164524/http://www.eagletribune.com/punews/local_story_271093855 "One year, 100,000 meals; Cor Unum reaches milestone feeding the hungry"], ''The Eagle-Tribune'', Lawrence, Massachusetts, September 28, 2007.</ref> The two are not related.
In January 2008, after his show was put on hold for two months owing to the [[2007–08 Writers Guild of America strike|strike by the Writers Guild of America]], he reemerged on late-night TV sporting a [[beard]], which guest [[Tom Brokaw]] described as making him look like "a draft dodger from the Civil War." After leaving ''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]'' on January 22, 2010, O'Brien again grew a beard, which he kept until May 2, 2011, when it was partially shaved on the set of his [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] talk show, ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'', by [[Will Ferrell]] with battery-operated clippers (and completely shaved off-screen by a professional barber).<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2011-05-04|url=http://teamcoco.com/content/watch-conans-beard-get-shaved-real-during-commercial-break|title=Watch Conan's Beard Get Shaved For Real During The Commercial Break|publisher=TeamCoco.com}}</ref> The event was dubbed on the show as "Beardpocalypse", and included a contest for fan-submitted artwork.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2011-05-04|url=http://teamcoco.com/content/slideshow-best-beardpocalypse-photoshop-contest-so-far?photo=8561|title=The Best of the Beardpocalypse Photoshop Contest|publisher=TeamCoco.com}}</ref>
O'Brien purchased a $10.5-million mansion in [[Brentwood, Los Angeles, California]], to prepare for his move there in 2009 from New York City to host ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' at [[Universal Studios Hollywood]].<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/sfgate/detail?blogid=7&entry_id=23616|title=O'Brien Spends Big in L.A.|work=San Francisco Chronicle | first=Karen | last=Reardanz | date=January 21, 2008}}</ref> As part of a long-running gag, he brought his 1992 [[Ford Taurus SHO]] with him to California, showcasing it on both the inaugural episodes of ''The Tonight Show'' and ''Conan''.
On June 12, 2011, O'Brien gave a commencement address to the class of 2011 at [[Dartmouth College]].
On October 21, 2011, O'Brien was ordained as a minister by the [[Universal Life Church Monastery]],<ref name="obrien">{{cite web|url = http://www.ulc.org/2011/10/universal-life-church-monastery-minister-conan-obrien-to-perform-gay-wedding/|title = Universal Life Church Monastery Minister Conan O'Brien to Perform Gay Wedding|publisher = Universal Life Church Monastery|date = October 28, 2011}}</ref><ref name="obrien2">{{cite web|url = http://www.themonastery.org/|title = Video of Conan O'Brien Getting Ordained – Universal Life Church Monastery|accessdate = February 5, 2012}}</ref> allowing him to perform a same-sex marriage while back in New York, then one of the few states in the US where gay marriage was legal, to tape a week's worth of shows. The wedding, between a member of O'Brien's staff and his partner, was held on the stage of the [[Beacon Theatre (New York City)|Beacon Theatre]] on November 3, 2011, and broadcast on ''Conan''.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/04/conan-obrien-gay-wedding_n_1075414.html Conan O'Brien Officiates Gay Wedding Of Scott Cronick And David Gorshein On Air (VIDEO)], ''Huffington Post'', November 4, 2011.</ref>
===Victim of stalking=== Starting in September 2006, O'Brien was [[Stalking|stalked]] by Father David Ajemian of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston|Archdiocese of Boston]], who, despite multiple warnings to stop, sent O'Brien letters signed as "your priest stalker" and came into contact with O'Brien's parents. O'Brien and Ajemian had attended [[Harvard University]] at the same time. Frustrated that he had been denied a spot in the ''Late Night'' audience, Ajemian sent a letter to O'Brien stating that he flew to New York "in the dimming hope that you might finally acknowledge me." He stated in another letter, "Is this the way you treat your most dangerous fans??? You owe me big time, pal." In another letter, Ajemian seemed to make a death threat, saying, "Remember [[Frank Costello]] once dodged a bullet in your building and so can you."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/08/arts/08conan.html|title=Priest Jailed in Stalking of Conan O’Brien|last=Lambert|first=Bruce|date=2007-11-08|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-27|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
Ajemian then tried to forcefully enter a taping of ''Late Night'' but was caught and arrested. He was previously warned by the NBC security team to stay away from the studio. After a psychological evaluation, he was deemed fit to stand trial. He was bailed out of jail.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://news.aol.com/entertainment/television/tv-news-story/ar/_a/conans-alleged-priest-stalker-in-court/20071108070609990001|title = Conan's Alleged 'Priest Stalker' in Court}}</ref> He was then reported missing by his father on November 10, 2007. He was found and underwent evaluation at a hospital. He was again found fit to stand trial on April 4, 2008. On April 8, Ajemian pleaded guilty to stalking, stating that he "never meant to cause anxiety or to upset anyone." He was ordered to pay a $95 court charge and to sign a two-year [[restraining order]] barring him from coming near O'Brien.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://news.aol.com/entertainment/story/_a/conan-obrien-stalker-pleads-guilty/n20080408181909990014|title = Conan Stalker Pleads Guilty}}</ref>
On September 11, 2008, Ajemian checked himself out of his treatment at a hospital against the wishes of his bishop, [[Seán Patrick O'Malley]]. Cardinal O'Malley then released a statement saying that, because he violated his bishop's wishes, Ajemian [[Defrocking|could no longer serve as a priest]] in the Catholic Church.<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/09/12/david-ajemian-conans-prie_n_125918.html|title = Conan O'Brien's Stalker Checks Out of Treatment|work = Huffington Post|date = September 12, 2008|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080915032034/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/09/12/david-ajemian-conans-prie_n_125918.html|archivedate = September 15, 2008|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2010/11/19/priest-in-conan-obrien-stalker-case-arrested-again/|title=Priest in Conan O’Brien stalker case arrested again|date=2010-11-19|work=New York Post|access-date=2017-09-27|language=en-US}}</ref> In late 2010, Ajemian was charged with harassing the TV host Anthony Everett while violating a restraining order.<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/11/19/david-ajemian-conan-obrie_n_785912.html|title = David Ajemian, Conan O'Brien's Stalker Priest, Arrested AGAIN|work = Huffington Post|date = November 19, 2010|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101124035530/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/11/19/david-ajemian-conan-obrie_n_785912.html|archivedate = November 24, 2010|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
